xyz.fsgek.common.net.tcp.handlers

Class LengthBasedTcpChannelHandler

  • java.lang.Object
    • xyz.fsgek.common.net.tcp.handlers.LengthBasedTcpChannelHandler
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    GekTcpChannelHandler<java.nio.ByteBuffer>

    public class LengthBasedTcpChannelHandler
extends java.lang.Object
implements GekTcpChannelHandler<java.nio.ByteBuffer>
    Length based handler implementation, to split passed byte buffer in length: 
         buffer -> data1data2data3..
    The returned object of onMessage(GekTcpChannel, ByteBuffer) is List<ByteBuffer>, each byte buffer is split in:
    • Fixed length: created by LengthBasedTcpChannelHandler(int) or LengthBasedTcpChannelHandler(int, IntFunction), to split in fixed length with GekBuffer.splitInLength(ByteBuffer, int) and make returned buffers readonly;
    • Specified length: created by LengthBasedTcpChannelHandler(int, int) or LengthBasedTcpChannelHandler(int, int, IntFunction), to split in specified length with GekBuffer.splitInLength(ByteBuffer, int, int) and make returned buffers readonly;

    • Method Detail

      • onMessage

        @Nullable
public @Nullable java.lang.Object onMessage(GekTcpChannel channel,
                                                       java.nio.ByteBuffer message)
        Description copied from interface: GekTcpChannelHandler
        Callback when new data has received.

        Server has a list of handlers, the first handler will be passed a ByteBuffer as message parameter, then returned object from first handler will be passed to next handler as message parameter, and so on. If null is returned from any handler, the handlers calling chain will be broken at that handler; if an exception is thrown, GekTcpServerHandler.onException(GekTcpChannel, Throwable, ByteBuffer) will be called and the calling chain will also be broken. The process like: 

             Object message = ByteBuffer.wrap(...);
     for (GekNetChannelHandler<...> channelHandler : channelHandlers) {
         try {
             Object result = channelHandler.onMessage(channel, message);
             if (result == null) {
                 break;
             }
             message = result;
         } catch (Throwable e) {
             serverHandler.onException(channel, e, remaining);
             break;
         }
     }
        If buffer of the channel is full, it will not read and put again. If the buffer on this callback is not fully consumed (remaining() > 0), the remaining data will be reserved to next calling. However, the handler chain will be called if and only if there has new data read from the remote endpoint. It's best to try to consume as much as possible for each time, or using GekTcpServerHandler.onLoop(GekTcpChannel, boolean, ByteBuffer) to deal with un-consumed data.
        Specified by:
        onMessage in interface GekTcpChannelHandler<java.nio.ByteBuffer>
        Parameters:
        channel - the channel
        message - the message
        Returns:
        result of callback
